title: Rabbit Fire
descriptions:
Rabbit Fire (1951) is a classic Warner Bros. Merrie Melodies short featuring Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck, and Elmer Fudd in one of their most iconic hunting-season battles of wits. The cartoon opens with Elmer creeping through the forest on the hunt, while Daffy lays down a trail of rabbit signs to steer Elmer toward Bugs. Daffy, eager to get Bugs out of the way, smugly points Elmer to Bugs’ hiding place. But Bugs turns the tables instantly with his verbal trickery, launching the legendary “duck season/rabbit season” debate.

What follows is a rapid-fire exchange where Bugs and Daffy manipulate Elmer’s target through clever wordplay and sign-switching. Bugs repeatedly convinces Elmer it’s duck season, then steps aside as Daffy haplessly declares, “Shoot him now! Shoot him now!”—only to realize too late he’s just gotten himself blasted. Each attempt by Daffy to recover—presenting “wabbit season” posters, trying to outsmart Bugs with legalistic logic—backfires, leading to a series of perfectly timed gags where Elmer keeps firing at Daffy, whose beak and feathers comically reassemble after every shot.

The core joke escalates into a meta-contest of slogans, reverse psychology, and slapstick, culminating in the famous pronoun bit where Bugs manipulates Daffy into demanding Elmer “shoot me now!” on the basis of grammatical correctness, resulting in yet another blast to Daffy’s face. Bugs remains unruffled, treating the entire affair as a playful game, while Daffy’s frustration grows into indignation and desperation.

Midway through, the tone shifts from simple sign-flipping to identity reversals. Bugs dons various disguises, at one point appearing as a glamorous female figure to further baffle Elmer, who obligingly follows the ruse. Daffy attempts counter-disguises and tactics, but Bugs effortlessly co-opts them, keeping Elmer’s aim fixed squarely on Daffy. The cartoon also features the famed “hunting season” cycle: duck season, rabbit season, and eventually a twist with Elmer season, each shift driven by visual gags and verbal trickery.

In the finale, the seasonal signs are escalated and overruled until Bugs produces “Elmer season,” prompting the hunter to flee as the tables fully turn. Daffy, momentarily triumphant, still can’t escape his fate, having been outmaneuvered at every turn. The short ends with Daffy’s exasperated acknowledgment of Bugs’ superiority and his own self-inflicted misfortunes, punctuated by one last gag at his expense.

Directed by Chuck Jones, with razor-sharp dialogue by Michael Maltese, Rabbit Fire is celebrated for introducing the “hunting trilogy” (continued in Rabbit Seasoning and Duck! Rabbit, Duck!) and for cementing the enduring dynamic: Bugs the cool-headed trickster, Daffy the combustible foil, and Elmer the earnest, hapless hunter caught in their verbal crossfire.
